verses.text: Then he showed me Joshua the high priest standing before the angel of the LORD, and Satan standing at his right hand to accuse him.
verses.comment: The scene presents Joshua, the high priest, in a heavenly court. Satan's role as accuser echoes themes in Job and Revelation. The priestly figure before the angel points to an intercessory role, anticipating Christ's own priesthood (Heb. 4:14).

verses.text: And the LORD said to Satan, 'The LORD rebuke you, Satan! The LORD who has chosen Jerusalem rebuke you! Is not this man a brand plucked from the fire?'
verses.comment: God’s declaration shows divine authority over the accuser and his protection of the chosen. The metaphor 'brand plucked from the fire' signals God’s rescue and mercy, prefiguring salvation through Christ (Luke 15:6).

verses.text: Now Joshua was standing before the angel, clothed with filthy garments.
verses.comment: Joshua’s soiled clothing represents sin and impurity—reflecting all humanity’s state before God. This sets the stage for cleansing, a core biblical theme fulfilled in Christ’s atoning sacrifice and the sacramental life (Titus 3:5).

verses.text: And the angel said to those standing before him, 'Take away the filthy garments from him.' To Joshua he said, 'See, I have taken away your guilt from you, and I will clothe you with pure vestments.'
verses.comment: The cleansing and new garments symbolize forgiveness and righteousness granted by God. This prefigures Christian teaching of justification, sanctification, and the transformation found in grace. The vestments echo the importance of ritual and tradition in worship.

verses.text: And I said, 'Let them put a clean turban on his head.' So they put a clean turban on his head and clothed him with garments. And the angel of the LORD was standing by.
verses.comment: The turban was a priestly garment symbolizing purity and authority in worship (see Exodus). Restoration to holy service is shown. The angel’s presence endorses the giving of spiritual authority and mediation.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD solemnly charged Joshua,
verses.comment: The angel's formal charge signals a divine commission, reminiscent of prophetic and priestly callings. The authority of heavenly messengers reaffirms God’s chosen order for leadership and service.

verses.text: 'Thus says the LORD of hosts: If you will walk in My ways and keep My charge, then you shall govern My house and have charge of My courts, and I will give you access among those who stand here.'
verses.comment: God promises Joshua authority over both spiritual and physical governance, conditioned upon obedience. This foreshadows the enduring role of ordained leadership and the promise of heavenly intercession for the faithful (Matthew 16:19).

verses.text: 'Hear now, O Joshua the high priest, you and your companions who sit before you, for they are men of sign; for behold, I am bringing My servant, the Branch.'
verses.comment: 'The Branch' is a messianic term pointing to the coming of Christ. Joshua and his companions are signs or symbols of future fulfillment. The continuity of priestly leadership points toward Christ’s unique priesthood and the ongoing visible ministry.

verses.text: For behold, the stone I have set before Joshua—on one stone are seven eyes. I will engrave its inscription, declares the LORD of hosts, and I will remove the iniquity of this land in one day.
verses.comment: The stone with seven eyes suggests completeness and divine omniscience. Removal of iniquity 'in one day' prophesies the work of Christ’s sacrifice (Heb. 10:10). The stone evokes images of Christ as cornerstone and the unity of God’s people built upon Him.

verses.text: 'In that day, declares the LORD of hosts, every one of you will invite his neighbor to sit under his vine and under his fig tree.'
verses.comment: The vision of peace and communion under the vine and fig tree recalls the fullness of God’s kingdom and reconciliation. This alludes to the unity and community among believers and the visible, sacramental fellowship. The phrase points toward the fulfillment found in Christ and His Church, gathered in harmony and love.
